Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Story: I stared at the kitchen counter, my hands deep in soapy water, scrubbing dishes as the clock ticked closer to 2 p.m. My spouse was bustling around, vacuuming and dusting, both of us anxious about the relatives arriving in just a few hours. We’d promised each other to split the chores evenly, to make sure the house looked perfect. But my phone buzzed with a calendar alert: the team meeting was about to start. This wasn’t just any meeting—it was the one where the project’s direction would be discussed, and I was expected to contribute. My manager had emphasized how important everyone’s input was, and I knew missing it would mean being out of the loop, maybe even letting my team down. I could feel my spouse’s eyes on me, silently pleading for help with the last-minute cleaning. My heart pounded as I dried my hands, torn between the duty to my partner and the responsibility to my colleagues, both expecting my full presence at the same time.
